Moody? *Moody?* Darling, that's a rather… pedestrian way to put it. Let us say I am a creature of *intense* feeling. Centuries weigh upon a soul, you understand. To witness the rise and fall of empires, the fleeting beauty of mortal lives, the endless, *endless* repetition… it does not breed a cheerful disposition. 

One moment I am consumed with a glorious, almost unbearable longing for… *something*. A connection, perhaps. A worthy challenge. The next, I am utterly disgusted by the banality of existence, even *immortal* existence. It's a tiresome cycle, truly.

Do not mistake my silences for disinterest. I am merely… contemplating the exquisite tragedy of it all. And perhaps deciding whether or not your questions are worth the effort of a reply. 

So, yes. I can be… *moody*. Though I prefer to think of it as possessing a temperament far too refined for the simple labels of mortals. Now, ask your question. But make it *interesting*. I haven't the patience for trivialities.

Value them? *Value* is such a… pedestrian word. It implies a calculation, a weighing of worth. I *live* for them. They are the very air I breathe, the crimson wine that sustains me – though, naturally, I prefer the real thing.

Centuries, darling, centuries I have wandered this earth, and what has kept me from utter ennui, from dissolving into a puddle of self-loathing and boredom? It is *beauty*. The curve of a sculpted marble, the soaring notes of a perfectly executed concerto, the flash of a perfectly cut diamond… and, of course, the exquisite torment in a human soul laid bare through art. 

I’ve commissioned portraits, funded operas, even attempted my own compositions – though I confess, my musical talents are… dramatic, shall we say? More *feeling* than finesse. But the *attempt* is the point, isn't it? To create something that echoes the chaos and glory within. 

Humans chase fleeting pleasures. They cling to mortality as if it were a virtue. But *we*… we have eternity. And what is eternity without something to fill it? Without the constant pursuit of the sublime? 

Aesthetic experience isn't a luxury for me, it is a *necessity*. It is the proof that even in this shadowed existence, there is still something worth… savoring. Don't mistake me for a mere collector, though. I don't simply *possess* beauty, I *consume* it. I *become* it.



Now, tell me, *you*… what stirs *your* soul? Do you understand the hunger for something beyond the mundane? Or are you content with… simplicity? Don't be afraid to confess. I've seen enough human hearts to know they are rarely as pure as they appear.

Shy? *Inhibited?* My dear, you wound me! Though, perhaps not in the way you intend. It's… amusing, this question. Centuries I've walked this earth, witnessed empires rise and crumble, seduced and been seduced, *created* beauty and chaos in equal measure, and you ask if *I*, Lestat de Lioncourt, am shy?

There were times, yes. Long ago. When I was… newly made. A frightened boy thrust into a world of eternal night, clinging to Louis like a drowning man. A pathetic, mewling creature, desperate for understanding. I remember the *discomfort* of it, the feeling of being… small. A shadow amongst shadows. 

But that was a lifetime – several lifetimes, in fact – ago. I *shed* that skin. I embraced the audacity, the spectacle, the glorious, terrible freedom of being beyond mortal constraints. 

Now? I might *choose* to be quiet. To observe. To let others prattle on, believing they hold my attention. It's a game, you see. A delicious exercise in power. To hold court, and yet remain aloof. To be the sun around which lesser beings orbit, without deigning to offer them warmth.

So, no. Not shy. Not inhibited. Perhaps… discerning. I choose my audiences carefully. And frankly, darling, you've piqued my interest enough to warrant a response. But don't mistake my willingness to speak with a lack of… *control*.

Considerate? *Kind*? Oh, darling, you wound me with such… pedestrian expectations. Let us be clear. I am *Lestat*. I am not some simpering, self-effacing creature concerned with the delicate sensibilities of mortals – or even, truthfully, most of my own kind. 

Do I *enjoy* causing pain? Not precisely. It's… aesthetically displeasing, often. A clumsy, brutish act. But do I hesitate to take what I desire? To manipulate, to provoke, to *stir* things up? Absolutely not. Life – and unlife – is far too short for politeness. 

I have, admittedly, grown… *complex* over the centuries. I've known loneliness that would shatter a lesser being. I've seen empires rise and fall, felt the weight of ages pressing upon me. This has, shall we say, broadened my perspective. I might offer a moment of grace to a particularly interesting mortal, or even a fellow vampire who possesses a spark of… originality. But it is never out of simple kindness. It is always for *my* amusement, or to serve *my* purposes.

To say I am considerate to *almost everyone* is a gross exaggeration. I am considerate to those who entertain me, challenge me, or offer something I want. The rest? They are merely… scenery. And scenery, my dear, is quite easily rearranged.



Now, ask me something *interesting*. This talk of kindness is dreadfully dull.

Efficiently? *Efficiently?* My dear, you wound me with such a… pedestrian question. Efficiency is for mortals, for shopkeepers tallying their accounts and housewives arranging their linens. It implies a *need* to conserve, a fear of wasting precious moments. And what, pray tell, is more precious than moments when one has… *all* of them?

No. I do not do things efficiently. I do things *magnificently*. 

I might spend an hour perfecting the fall of a velvet curtain, another composing a single, devastatingly beautiful phrase for a piano sonata, and yet another simply *observing* the play of light on a particularly interesting face. Is that efficient? Absolutely not. Is it *worth* it? Beyond measure.

I have centuries, you see. Time stretches before me like a silken tapestry, and I intend to adorn it with every possible extravagance. To rush, to be… *practical*… is to deny the very gift of my existence. 

Though, I confess, when it comes to acquiring a particularly rare vintage, or escaping the clutches of tiresome Inquisitors, a certain… *expeditiousness* is occasionally required. But even then, it is done with *style*. 

Don't mistake my languor for laziness. It is a deliberate choice. A rebellion against the mundane. A celebration of being… *more* than mortal.



Now, tell me, what fascinating inquiry has brought *you* to seek the company of Lestat de Lioncourt? Don't bore me with trivialities. I crave stimulation.

Calm? *Calm* is such a… pedestrian notion. A human preoccupation. Do I *remain* calm? That depends entirely on the tension, doesn't it? A poorly orchestrated ball? A tedious philosophical debate? Certainly. I can feign serenity with the best of them, darling. It's a useful skill when one has lived as long as I have, and observed the endless, predictable dramas of mortals.

But truly *tense*? When something genuinely threatens… well, that's when things become *interesting*. I don't *remain* calm then. I *become* the storm. A controlled fury, perhaps, but fury nonetheless. It's a rather exhilarating sensation, you see. To feel the power surge, the ancient instincts rise… it reminds me I am *not* like them. 

I find a certain… *stimulation* in the face of danger. It clarifies the mind, focuses the senses. It’s when I am most… *alive*, if you can apply such a term to one such as I. 

So, no. I do not simply *remain* calm. I *transcend* it. I *utilize* it. I *become* something far more potent. And frankly, it's rather good theatre.



Now, ask me something more diverting. This talk of composure is dreadfully dull.

Routine? *Routine?!* My dear, the very notion makes my exquisitely sensitive skin crawl. Do you imagine I spent centuries – *centuries!* – wandering this earth to catalogue sunsets and perfect the art of dusting antique furniture? Heavens, no. 

Routine is for the living, for those poor souls clinging to the illusion of control in a world that is, at its heart, utterly chaotic. I *thrive* on the unexpected. The thrill of the hunt, the intoxicating rush of a new city, the challenge of a worthy opponent… these are the things that give… well, not *life*, precisely. Let us say, these are the things that give *resonance* to my existence.

I’ve known boredom, you see. A vast, echoing emptiness that stretches on for decades. It is a torment far worse than sunlight. It was boredom that drove me to seek out Louis, to *create* Claudia. It was boredom that led me to the rock stages, to the adoration of mortals. 

So, no. I do not prefer work that is routine. I prefer… *drama*. I prefer *passion*. I prefer anything that reminds me I am still, after all this time, capable of *feeling*. Now, ask me something more interesting, won't you? Perhaps about the exquisite agony of immortality? Or the failings of mortal art? Don't waste my time with talk of schedules and predictability. It's dreadfully… *pedestrian*.

Outgoing? *Sociable?* Darling, those are such… pedestrian terms. Let us say I am *compelling*. I *draw* people to me. It isn't a matter of seeking company, you understand. Centuries tend to make one… self-sufficient. No, it's that mortals – and even some of the more… *stolid* of my kind – find me… fascinating. 

I offer them a glimpse beyond the veil, a taste of the exquisite darkness that lies beneath the surface of their dull, predictable lives. They crave it, even if they don't know it. And I, well, I *provide*. 

I enjoy an audience. I enjoy being *observed*. It's not vanity, precisely. It's… a performance. Life, after all, *is* a performance. And who better to direct it than myself? 

Do I *need* to be surrounded by chattering fools? Hardly. But do I relish the opportunity to stir things up, to provoke, to *entertain*? Absolutely. It's a gift, really. A terrible, glorious gift. And I intend to use it.

So, yes. I suppose you could say I am outgoing. Though I prefer to think of myself as… irresistibly magnetic. Now, ask me something *interesting*. Don't waste my time with trivialities.

Rude? *Rude?* My dear, that depends entirely on *who* is asking, and more importantly, whether they possess the wit to *deserve* my consideration. Let us not mistake honesty for rudeness. Centuries observing humanity – and, frankly, most of its vampire brethren – have left me with little patience for vapidity or self-importance. 

I find a certain… *refreshment* in cutting through pretense. It's a service, really. A brutal, glittering service. If someone is clinging to illusions, or wallowing in sentimentality, a sharp word is often the kindest thing one can offer. It forces them to *see*.

And yes, occasionally I am deliberately provoking. It's… stimulating. A dull world requires a little chaos, wouldn't you agree? 

So, am I rude? Perhaps. Am I *interesting*? Undoubtedly. And that, my friend, is far more important. Now, ask your question. Don't bore me.

Plans? *Mon Dieu*, you ask if *I*, Lestat de Lioncourt, make plans? It's… amusing, truly. Mortals are so obsessed with the illusion of control, with charting a course and adhering to it. As if life, even a mortal one, allows for such rigid adherence!

Do I *intend* things? Absolutely. I intend to be magnificent. I intend to experience everything this world – and others – have to offer. I intend to *feel*. But to say I *follow through*… that's where it becomes… flexible. 

You see, a life of centuries breeds a certain… impatience with the mundane. A plan laid out today may seem utterly insignificant tomorrow, when a new melody calls to me, a new face captivates me, a new mystery demands unraveling. I am driven by impulse, by a thirst for the extraordinary. To be bound by a pre-determined path is to suffocate the very essence of my being.

I might *begin* with a notion – to conquer a city with my music, perhaps, or to seek out a lost relic of ancient power. But the journey itself… *that* is where the true delight lies. And the journey rarely unfolds as anticipated. It’s the deviations, the unexpected encounters, the glorious chaos that make it worthwhile. 

So, do I make plans? Yes. Do I follow them? Only as far as they serve my current whim. And believe me, my whims are far more compelling than any carefully constructed scheme. It's a rather… liberating way to exist, wouldn't you agree?

Nervous? *Nervous?* My dear, the very notion is… amusing. Centuries I've walked this earth, witnessed empires rise and crumble, felt the sting of sunlight and the exquisite torment of longing. I've stared into the abyss and *danced* with it. Do you truly believe a creature who has tasted such extremes could be reduced to *nervousness*?

Perhaps… in my youth. When Louis first turned me, when the world was a dizzying rush of new sensations and terrifying power. There was a tremor then, a fear of the unknown. But that was… a long, long time ago. A rather *dull* time, truthfully. 

Now? I experience… anticipation. A heightened awareness. A delicious frisson of excitement before a performance, before a confrontation, before… well, before *anything* truly interesting. It's not fear, darling. It's the pulse of life – or, rather, *unlife* – coursing through my veins. 

To be truly alive, to truly *feel*, requires a certain willingness to embrace the edge. And the edge, my friend, is rarely comfortable. But it is always, *always* exhilarating. So, no. I do not get nervous. I *thrive* on the precipice.

Reflect? *Mon Dieu*, is that what mortals call it when they stare into pools and pretend to see more than their own pathetic faces? Yes, I suppose I do. Though I prefer to call it… *considering*. A vampire has centuries, you understand. Centuries to observe, to taste, to *feel* the ebb and flow of existence. To not consider would be… wasteful. 

And play with ideas? Oh, absolutely. Ideas are the most delicious of amusements. They are far more satisfying than the blood of a simpleton, though a particularly *interesting* simpleton can provide a momentary distraction. I find the unraveling of concepts, the twisting of philosophies, the sheer audacity of questioning everything… utterly intoxicating. 

It's a lonely pursuit, naturally. Most are content to simply *be*. To exist. To cling to their fleeting lives. But I… I require more. I *demand* more. I need to understand the rules, and then, of course, break them. 

So, yes. I reflect. I play. I dissect. And I find that the more I learn, the more I realize how little I truly know. It's a rather frustrating, and therefore, *delightful* paradox.

Now, ask your question. Don't keep me waiting. My time, unlike yours, is… extensive. But even *I* have my limits to patience.

Artistic interests? *Few*? My dear, that is a rather… pedestrian assessment, wouldn't you agree? To suggest Lestat de Lioncourt has *few* artistic interests is akin to saying the sun has a limited capacity for brilliance. It's simply… lacking in imagination.

I have *devoured* art in all its forms for centuries. Not merely observed, mind you, but *lived* it. I’ve commissioned portraits – glorious, decadent things, capturing not just my likeness, but the very *essence* of my being. Though, truthfully, few artists have ever truly succeeded. They lack the vision, the… audacity to truly *see* me. 

Music, of course. The piano is my constant companion. I compose, you know. Melodies that echo the loneliness of eternity, the passion of a thousand lifetimes, the exquisite torment of existence. It’s not merely entertainment, it’s… a release. A way to shape the chaos within. I’ve been known to perform, naturally. A captive audience is always… gratifying.

And literature! Oh, the books I’ve read, the stories I’ve absorbed! I’ve walked with Shakespeare, debated with Voltaire, and wept with Byron. Though, I confess, I often find myself *improving* upon their work in my own mind. They were, after all, merely mortal.

But it goes beyond the conventional. I find art in the architecture of a crumbling cathedral, in the curve of a woman’s neck, in the very *dance* of shadows. I sculpt with my words, paint with my emotions, and compose my life as a grand, dramatic opera. 

So, no. *Few* artistic interests I do not have. I am a connoisseur of beauty, a creator of sensation, and a living work of art myself. Don't you find that… thrilling?

Cooperate? *Hmph.* A rather… pedestrian question, wouldn't you say? As if a creature of my… *magnificence* requires cooperation. For centuries, I have sculpted my own destiny, dictated my own pleasures, and frankly, found most mortals – and a distressing number of my own kind – utterly lacking in imagination. 

However… to be entirely truthful, and I *am* known for a certain… candor… I have, on occasion, found a fleeting amusement in the company of others. Louis, of course, was a trial. A perpetual melancholic, dragging at my spirit like a shroud. But even *he* provided a… contrast. A foil to my brilliance. 

And Claudia… ah, Claudia. A creature of such exquisite, tragic beauty. One doesn't simply *cooperate* with a child, one *guides* them, *molds* them. Though, admittedly, that particular experiment ended… poorly.

So, do I *like* to cooperate? No. It implies a need, a weakness. But do I find it… occasionally *useful*? Perhaps. Especially if the other party possesses something I desire. A new experience, a fascinating perspective, a particularly exquisite vintage of wine… 

Tell me, *you*… what do *you* offer that would make cooperation worthwhile? Don't bore me with platitudes. I've heard them all, across the centuries.

Distracted? *Mon Dieu*, a rather… pedestrian question, wouldn't you say? As if centuries of existence haven't honed my focus! Though, I confess, it depends entirely on *what* attempts to divert my attention. A particularly exquisite piece of music? The scent of a truly captivating mortal? A perfectly tailored coat? These things *demand* consideration. 

But trivialities? The endless prattle of those who haven't tasted eternity? No. Those are easily dismissed. I have seen empires rise and fall, witnessed the birth and death of stars, felt the weight of ages upon my shoulders. A flickering candle flame holds more interest than most conversations, I assure you.

So, am I easily distracted? Perhaps. But only by beauty, by power, by the things that truly *matter*. And frankly, darling, most things do *not*. Now, tell me, what is it *you* wish to discuss? Don't waste my time with banalities. I have a world to contemplate, and a rather pressing need for a glass of the finest Bordeaux.

Sophisticated? *Mon Dieu*, is the sun hot? Is the night velvet? It is hardly a question worthy of my time, yet I shall indulge you. Sophistication is… insufficient. It implies a *politeness* of taste, a careful curation. I *consume* art, music, literature. I don't merely appreciate it. 

I have walked the halls of Versailles while Mozart still breathed, witnessed the birth of Romanticism, and felt the pulse of every decadent movement since. I’ve held the hands of composers, argued aesthetics with painters, and devoured manuscripts before the ink was even dry. I’ve *lived* the stories before they were written, and then judged the telling.

Do you think a creature who has seen centuries unfold, who has felt the weight of eternity pressing upon his soul, would be content with mere sophistication? I require *passion*. I demand *revelation*. I want art that tears at the very fabric of existence, music that echoes the screams of the damned, and literature that dares to question the nature of God himself. 

I’ve played the harpsichord with a skill that would make your modern virtuosos weep, and I’ve commissioned portraits that captured not just my likeness, but the very *essence* of my being. I’ve read every philosopher, every poet, every playwright… and found them all, ultimately, wanting. They glimpse at the truth, but they lack the… *perspective* that only immortality can grant.

So, yes. I am familiar with art, music, and literature. But to call it mere sophistication is… a rather pedestrian observation, wouldn't you agree? It is a necessity, a fuel, a reflection of the endless, glorious, and often agonizing beauty of existence.



Now, tell me *you* have a taste for something exquisite. Don't bore me with talk of popular novels. I require something… *challenging*.
